0.text: The world we live in feels normal, ordinary.

3.text: It feels like this is just how humans exist and always existed.

11.text: Never before have we humans lived in a world as sophisticated and engineered to our needs as today.

18.text: Giving us the luxury to forget about ourselves and not worry about survival.

24.text: Food, shelter, security – all of this is, more or less, taken for granted.

29.text: But we're a special few; for more than 99.99% of human history, life was completely different.

36.text: And there's no such thing as just one human history.

49.text: Our story begins 6 million years ago, when the tribe of hominini split and our relationship with the apes ended.

56.text: 2.8 million years ago, the genus of homo, the first humans, emerged.

62.text: We like to think about ourselves as the only humans, but this is far from the truth.

67.text: When we, homo sapiens sapiens, came into existence 200,000 years ago, there were at least six other human species around.

75.text: Cousins of comparable intelligence and ability, which must have been incredibly scary, kind of like living with aliens.

83.text: Some of them were very successful.

86.text: Homo erectus, for example, survived for 2 million years.

90.text: Ten times longer than modern humans have existed.

93.text: The last of the other humans disappeared around 10,000 years ago.

98.text: We don't know what caused them to die out.

101.text: Modern humans have at least a few percent of neanderthal and other human DNA, so there was some mixing,

106.text: but certainly not enough to be a merger between species.

110.text: So we don't know if our cousins went away because they lost the battle over resources, or because of a series of minor genocides.

120.text: Back to the beginnings of humanity.

122.text: 2.8 million years ago, early humans used tools, but did not make a lot of progress for nearly 2 million years.

129.text: Until they learned to control fire.

132.text: Fire meant cooking, which made food more nutritious, which contributed to the development of our brain.

139.text: It also produced light and warmth, which made days longer and winters less gruesome.

144.text: On top of that, it not only scared predators away, it could also be used for hunting.

149.text: A torched wood or grassland provided small animals, nuts and tubers that were pre-roasted.

155.text: From 300,000 years ago, most of the different human species lived in small hunter-gatherer societies.

162.text: They had fire, wood and stone tools, planned for the future, buried their dead, and had cultures of their own.

169.text: But most importantly, they spoke to each other.

172.text: Probably in a kind of proto-language, less complex than ours.

176.text: If we had a time machine, how far would we be able to go back,

181.text: steal a few babies and raise them today without anyone noticing that they're a bit different?

189.text: Anatomically, modern humans emerged 200,000 years ago,

193.text: but probably 70,000 years is as far as we could travel back and still snatch a behaviourally modern human.

200.text: Before that, the babies would probably lack a few crucial gene mutations

204.text: Necessary to build a brain with modern language and abstract thinking abilities.

209.text: At some point, around 50,000 years ago, there was an explosion in innovation.

214.text: Tools and weapons became more sophisticated and culture became more complex,

219.text: because at this point, humans had a multi-purpose brain,

222.text: and a more advanced language to communicate information with each other effectively,

226.text: and down to the last detail.

228.text: This allowed much closer cooperation, and is what really makes us different from any other creature on Earth.

235.text: Not our comparatively weak bodies and inferior senses,

238.text: but the ability to cooperate flexibly in large groups, unlike, for example, rigid beehives

245.text: or intimate, but tiny wolf packs.

248.text: As our brain evolved, we became able to do something, life had been unable to do up to this point.

257.text: Two – preserve the knowledge gained over generations.

261.text: Three – build on past knowledge, to gain even deeper insight.

266.text: This seems daft, but until then, information had to be passed on from generation to generation,

272.text: mostly through genetics, which is not efficient.

276.text: Still, for the next 40,000 years, human life remained more or less the same.

281.text: There was little to build upon.

283.text: Our ancestors were only one animal among many.

287.text: Building a skyscraper without knowing what a house is… is hard.

291.text: But while it is easy to be arrogant in our attitude to our ancestors, this would be ignorant.

296.text: Humans 50,000 years ago were survival specialists.

300.text: They had a detailed mental map of their territory,

303.text: their senses were fine-tuned to the environment,

305.text: they knew and memorized a great amount of information about plants and animals.

310.text: They could make complicated tools that required years of careful training and very fine motor skills

317.text: Their bodies compared to our athletes today just because of their daily routines,

321.text: and they lived a rich social life within their tribe

324.text: Survival required so many skills that the average brain volume of early modern humans

330.text: might even have been bigger than it is today

332.text: As a group we know more today, but as individuals our ancestors were superior to us

339.text: But then around 12,000 years ago, in multiple locations, humans developed agriculture.

347.text: Before, survival as a hunter and forager required superb physical and mental abilities in all fields from everybody

354.text: With the rise of the agricultural age, individuals could increasingly rely on the skills of others for survival.

362.text: This meant that some of them could specialize.

364.text: Maybe they worked on better tools, maybe they took time to breed more resistant crops or better livestock,

373.text: As farming got more and more efficient, what we call civilization began

378.text: Agriculture gave us a reliable and predictable food source,

381.text: which allowed humans to hoard food on a large scale for the first time,

384.text: which is much easier to do with grains than meat,

387.text: The food stock required protection, which led to communities living together in tighter spaces

393.text: First, early defense structures were built, the need for organization grew

397.text: The more organized we got, the faster things became efficient

401.text: Villages became cities, cities became kingdoms, kingdoms became empires

408.text: Connections between humans exploded which led to opportunities to exchange knowledge

416.text: About 500 years ago the Scientific Revolution began

420.text: Mathematics, Physics, Astronomy, Biology, and Chemistry transformed everything we thought we knew

427.text: The Industrial Revolution followed soon after laying the foundation for the modern world

433.text: As our overall efficiency grew exponentially,

435.text: more people could spend their lifetime contributing to the progress of humanity

441.text: The invention of the computer, its evolution into a medium we all use on a daily basis,

446.text: and the rise of the Internet shaped our world

450.text: It's hard to grasp how fast all of that happened

453.text: It's been about 125,000 generations since the emergence of the first human species

459.text: About 7,500 generations since the physiologically modern humans saw the light of day

465.text: 500 generations ago, what we call civilization began

469.text: 20 generations ago, we learned how to do science

473.text: And the Internet became available to most people only one generation ago

477.text: Today we live in the most prosperous age humanity has ever experienced

482.text: We have transformed this planet, from the composition of its atmosphere to large-scale changes in its landscape

488.text: and also in terms of the other animals in existence.

492.text: We light up the night with artificial stars and put people in a metal box in the sky

497.text: Some have even walked on our Moon

499.text: We put robots on other planets

501.text: We've looked deep into the past of the universe with mechanical eyes

505.text: Our knowledge and our way of acquiring and storing more of it has exploded

510.text: The average high school student today knows more about the universe than a scholar a few centuries ago

515.text: Humans dominate this planet, even if our rule is very fragile

521.text: We are still not that different from our ancestors 70,000 years ago

525.text: But your lifestyle has existed for less than 0.001% of human history

531.text: From here on, there's no saying what the future holds for us

536.text: We're building a skyscraper, but we're not sure if it's standing on a solid foundation

540.text: or if we're building it on quicksand

543.text: Let's leave it with that for now

544.text: The next time you miss your train, your burger is not hot enough, or someone cuts in line

549.text: Remember how special this made-up human world is

552.text: Maybe it's not worth being upset about all those little things.
